subject: Re: [junit] Re: Final Class (default accessibility) organization
msgSnippet: ... I read and understood your limitations.  The fact of the matter is the JVM is specifically design not to allow access to package-protected classes in other
messageBody:
idebug65 wrote:

> --- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> > idebug65 wrote:
> >
> > > I have a class (a final class) which uses default accessibility.
> I
> > > would like to organize my test cases in a separate
> package/directory,
> > > but I'm having difficulty because I can not access my class.
> > > Currently, I have the unit test file soft linked into my
> production
> > > package, and this is working. But this can get messy when dealing
> > > with many files and packages. Is there a more graceful way of
> doing
> > > this?
> > >
> >
> > a) Organize test cases in the same package as the class under test
> > b) Change the accessibility of the class under test
> >
> > ------------------
> But a and b are the things that I don't want to do, if you read my
> original message. There are many reasons why I need it in a
> different directory. Also to change the production code just to
> satisfy unit testing doesn't sound so good. There is a reason why we
> didn't want to make it public. So do you know of any graceful way of
> doing this besides a and b?
>

I read and understood your limitations. The fact of the matter is the JVM is
specifically design not to allow access to package-protected classes in other
packages. So I'm offering the best advice I have given that constraint.

By the way, organizing the test classes in the same packages doesn't mean the
source code has to be in the same directory. I use a parallel (mirrored)
directory structure to avoid lumping everything in the same directory.

Some have offered reflection as an alternative to (a) and (b) above, as
well.

"Doctor, it hurts when I put my code and its tests in different packages, and
then try to test non-public methods."

Mike
